title: Using /srv for a Personal Developer Repository Bank
context: As a solo developer, I decided to use /srv/ as the root for my local repository bank because it aligns with professional system administration standards.
keyIdea: /srv is a valid and standards-compliant location for service or project data according to the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard (FHS). Even as a personal developer, using /srv/dev-repos provides a professional and organized directory structure for version-controlled projects.
commands:
```bash
# Create the central repository directory under /srv
sudo mkdir -p /srv/dev-repos/{personal,work,open-source,archive}

# Set ownership to current user for easier management
sudo chown -R $USER:$USER /srv/dev-repos

# Optionally, create a group for future scalability
sudo groupadd developers
sudo usermod -aG developers $USER
sudo chown -R root:developers /srv/dev-repos
sudo chmod -R 2775 /srv/dev-repos

# Set environment variable for convenience
echo 'export DEV_REPOS=/srv/dev-repos' >> ~/.bashrc
echo "alias cdrepo='cd $DEV_REPOS'" >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc
```
explanation: Even for personal setups, using /srv for a developer repository bank adds consistency with professional Linux filesystem conventions. It also simplifies transitioning to multi-user or server environments later on, since /srv is recognized as a standard data service directory.

reusabilityNotes.whenToReuse: Use this structure when setting up a personal or multi-user system where development repositories should be centrally located and managed with consistent permissions.
reusabilityNotes.pitfalls: Ensure correct permissions and group ownership. Avoid running user applications as root inside /srv. Always use chmod 2775 to preserve group inheritance for shared directories.
